message_1: Consider the relevance logic statement: "If John is studying for his math exam, then he will pass the exam." Assume that it is known that John did not pass the exam. Determine whether or not John was studying for his math exam.
message_2:
Let's use the following symbols to represent the statements:

P: John is studying for his math exam.
Q: John will pass the exam.

The given relevance logic statement can be represented as:

If P, then Q (P → Q)

We are also given that John did not pass the exam, which means ¬Q is true.

Now, we want to determine whether or not John was studying for his math exam (P).

Using the contrapositive rule, we know that:

(P → Q) is equivalent to (¬Q → ¬P)

Since ¬Q is true, we can conclude that ¬P is also true, which means John was not studying for his math exam.
